It was a business email.
Back when I started, PR companies would love to talk to me. I got very friendly with a few of them. Some would even offer writing advice from time to time (they knew I was new to the industry). Now the experience is a lot less personal.

I syndicate articles to about 6 sites, with the number growing.
I stated to Nintendo I wanted an early copy for review. I then said I was British (whcih I am), but live in Sweden BUT I only work with British sites. At that point, they decided they did not want to work with me and blocked me.
It has always been the larger companies that have been willing to send me games. The day I started up my first site, I was straight on EA's mailing list. I received every single release of theirs on multiple formats for the next 3 years. These were physical copies. I have not really done much since everybody moved over to digital games.
I did not have a single company that refused to deal with me when I was a smaller business, but now I have a reach that is 30-40x larger than it was before, nobody wants to give me the time of day.
And choosing the distributor in this manner would be seen as a PR move, in my opinion.
And many more people would prefer The Elder Scrolls, which is the more popular franchise.
A lot of people use the same usernames on multiple sites. One of my old accounts, you could have just Googled my username and you would find my dating profile, Facebook etc.

I have reported numerous posts on here to the British police which threaten violence against minorities i.e. "I wish I could go out there and kill all the Muslims". Mainly because you don't want somebody with that sort of thinking as they could be 'triggered' at some point and try and kill somebody.
I don't see what is inherently wrong with that post, though.

WRITING.TITLE: Has the process of requesting review copies changed?
WRITING.TEXT:
Back when I got started (2004-ish), I was able to *easily* get review copies for a brand new site, 100ish visitors per day. Every company would respond to me. I had 20+ review copies coming my way each week, all for a small website.
I then got out of the game for a while. I want to get back into games journalism, just to spice my writing life up a bit. However, nobody responds to me. Nintendo of Europe even blocked my email account. Kalypso Media said I could have a review copy then went dead on me.
Is the traditional website dead? If I really want to score review copies, do I need to produce videos nowadays?
I mean, I can easily buy my own games for review, which is fine. It just seems like a changed industry.

It is a bit more complicated than that, but imagine the Queen is similar to the President in terms of her power, but she just delegates that power to somebody else, which would be the PM.
Very easy to claim adverse possession on property in the UK. You are going to be successful *most* of the time.

The Prime Minister is the head of the executive branch, sort of. The monarch is really the executive, but the Prime Minister and her Government (selected from Parliament) acts on behalf of the monarch.
The monarch still has a surprising amount of power, but most of it is left in the hands of the government. Basically, you think of the PM as acting on behalf of the monarch. The monarch still needs to sign legislation before it becomes the law, and she still needs to choose the PM (she is advised on who to pick).
In Parliament (the legislature), the PM has just as much power as every other MP in that room on a voting level.

I ran a history website for a while. Focused solely on British history.
Produce quality articles *for children*, give Amazon links for 'further reading', and you have a decent business. Granted, this is not 'academic style' as you are focusing on children, but still.

I always go with 100% upfront for 99.9% of my clients. If I have worked with the client for years and I know they won't fail to pay, I give them a bit of leeway and allow them to pay on the day the content is due (happens 100% of the time). But new clients, no way are they paying 50% up front.

I moved to Sweden from the UK.
Hardest part was saying goodbye to my dog.
Each and every time I went back, I had to say goodbye to my dog, not knowing whether it would be the last time I would see her. She was so happy to see me when I returned, even after a year away. She knew it was me.
Turns out that in March, it was the last time I would ever see my dog. She would not even know it. She was probably still waiting there, right up until she took her final breath, for me to return.
